B0001CKGOM|5.0|Given the number of excellent movies that have been made about sailing ships and the breadth of coverage of those movies, at first you might wonder how yet another movie is going to add anything to the genre. If you have seen this movie you need no answer to that question. This story is as compelling as \\"Moby Dick,\\" and the captain of H.M.S. Surprise is just as driven as Captain Ahab, though generally not mad as was Ahab.<br /><br />The story at first appears to be a classic story of a strategic sea chase between two captains. However, it cannot be, for the pursuer and the pursued frequently change position, and the English pursuer is the weaker of the two opponents. In order to have any chance against an enemy with longer range guns, more speed, and a nearly impenetrable hull, Captain Jack Aubrey (Russell Crowe) will need luck, bravery, and a superb strategy. Fortunately all three will eventually work in his favor, at least sufficiently to make a grand finish to this movie.<br /><br />Three things set this movie apart from its predecessors.<br /><br />First, the detail in this movie is incredibly good. The research into the conditions about a sailing ship of this era was apparently quite extensive as the details in the operation of the ship were numerous. Details regarding the relationships between the officers and crew also appeared quite authentic, recalling from my dim past the book \\"Two Years Before the Mast.\\" While it would be easy to dismiss the attention to detail, that very detail makes much of this movie a delight to watch.<br /><br />Secondly, the two captains were every bit as crafty as any two captains have ever been portrayed. We only see the results of the French captain's efforts, but we see the result of those efforts on Captain Aubrey, and we realize that Captain Aubrey has met someone with a talent that is at least equal to his own. We have seen similar scenarios in movies such as \\"The Enemy Below\\" and \\"Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan,\\" and yet in every one of these movies the scenario, while similar, is sufficiently different that you will find the course of the movie and the ending to be different.<br /><br />Third, the special effects benefit from decades of development of computer generated imagery. In the movies of days gone by the special effects would rely heavily on miniature ships floating about in a big pool. In this movie the special effects are so good that, just as in \\"Jurassic Park,\\" you never know when you are looking at a ship and when you are looking at computer graphics. While there are places where you can guess computer images were used, try not to focus on that aspect too much because it can distract you from the story.<br /><br />Russell Crowe gives an outstanding performance as Captain Aubrey, well supported by a similarly excellent cast. \\"Master and Commander\\" received ten nominations for Academy Awards in 2003, and in any other year would likely have won many more awards than the two it won, but \\"The Return of the King\\" overshadowed this superb historical fiction. It is gratifying to see such quality in film making. This movie is well worth five stars and then some.<br /><br />Enjoy!d yet in every one of these movies the scenario, while similar, is sufficiently different that you will find the course of the movie and the ending to be different. <br /> <br />Third, the special effects benefit from decades of development of computer generated imagery. B000002HPV|5.0|I had a similar experience with Homogenic as some other reviewers- what once seemed cold and alienating became my personal favorite.<br /><br />Homogenic could be regarded as Bjork's bridge album.  The early part of her solo career established her as a late-night MTV video darling, and alterna-pop culture icon.  Later on, cynicism set in, and she became a walking punchline, turning up on worst-dressed lists, not to mention celebrities gone bezerk.  Coincidentially, her music became more personal and obtuse, alienating passers-by, but endearing her more to the faithful.<br /><br />If you liked the It's Oh So Quiet incarnation of Bjork, well, she left the party quite some time ago.  In her place is Hunter Bjork.  Hunter throws down the gauntlet, mildly shocking you with its sinuous, military-march beat and eleventh-hour urgency.  This song quickly became a favorite, even before I came to appreciate the album as a whole.  Interestingly, Bjork said in an interview that this song is about having to \\"output\\" as a music artist, so that the small army of assistants around you can continue to have work.  It's a very pithy statement. Bjork infers that if she's gonna output, it won't be the usual cutesy-pie, cuddly affairs that come at the expense of artistic sensibility.<br /><br />Joga, the first single, is a triumph, every bit as urgent as Hunter, and perfectly crafted.  Here and elsewhere on Homogenic, Bjork proves that strings-and-synth is a potent combination.  Unravel, the third track, foreshadows later albums.  It has a rather morose, almost funereal atmosphere.  It's a love song, but the mood is brooding and wistful.  Midway through, an organ piano is introduced, lending a dirge-like element.<br /><br />Bachelorette could just as well be titled Isobel, Act II. I say \\"Act II\\" and not \\"part two,\\" because this is NOT just a repeat song with different lyrics.  It builds on the operatic quality of Isobel (from Post), quickening the pulse and emotion.  The twin nature of Isobel and Bachelorette is a firm testament to Bjork's musicianship.<br /><br />All Neon Like is the only weak link in Homogenic, in my opinion.  The lyics are fascinating, but that \\"duh-duh, dum-dum-dum\\" bassline beat irritates.  Far better is Five Years.  Now, this is Bjork that fascinates me.  First, the harsh reproachment of a former lover is compelling.  Bjork doesn't indulge in Alanis Morrisette \\"You Oughta Know\\" histrionics.  Her statement is bolder, less cliche.  She won't torch your clothes and your car, but she'll dare you, and take you to task for being a coward who can't handle a serious relationship.  I just love the way she sings, \\"I dare you\\" with every fiber of her being.  Second, the sonic landscape.  The song is dominated early on by a harsh beat that's like a distorted transmission from outer space, or a foray though an asteroid belt.  Then, it yield to ravishing strings.  This is pure genius.<br /><br />Immature bears the closest resemblance to her earlier albums.  The sound has a percolating, almost jazzy feel.  The lyrics are very minimal, but the way she sings them is addictive.  I can't help but want to sing along.  The feel-good sentiment continues with Alarm Call.<br /><br />Pluto is the most extreme song of the album, a blistering barrage of sounds, like sparks flying from a blown-out circuit.  Her distorted vocals make her sound like she sang them through a high-speed fan.<br /><br />From the harsh landscape of Pluto emerges All is Full of Love.  The ethereal, mellifluous strings and lovingly-sung lyrics end the album on a sublime note.  It doesn't hurt that the video made for the song is one of the very best ever made.<br /><br />Homogenic is a brilliantly executed album, one that will reward you time and again.re of Isobel and Bachelorette is a firm testament to Bjork's musicianship.   <br /> <br />All Neon Like is the only weak link in Homogenic, in my opinion.  The lyics are fascinating, but that \\"duh-duh, dum-dum-dum\\" bassline beat irritates.  Far better is Five Years.  Now, this is Bjork that fascinates me.  First, the harsh reproachment of a former lover is compelling.  Bjork doesn't indulge in Alanis Morrisette \\"You Oughta Know\\" histrionics.  Her statement is bolder, less cliche.  She won't torch your clothes and your car, but she'll dare you, and take you to task for being a coward who can't handle a serious relationship.  I just love the way she sings, \\"I dare you\\" with every fiber of her being.  Second, the sonic landscape. This is pure genius. <br /> <br />Immature bears the closest resemblance to her earlier albums.  The sound has a percolating, almost jazzy feel.  The lyrics are very minimal, but the way she sings them is addictive.  I can't help but want to sing along. It doesn't hurt that the video made for the song is one of the very best ever made. <br /> <br />Homogenic is a brilliantly executed album, one that will reward you time and again. <br />

Fans of the trilogy that have yet to buy the DVDs will find this set a great one to have.<br /><br />\\"Jurassic Park\\" introduced us to digital dinosaurs and how fearsome they could be with modern computer technology. The bumps in the actions of the characters just did not allow me to focus on the plot throughout. Another problem with this movie is that it focused too much on action, and very little on the characters themselves. Thus, the movie comes across as more of a cartoon than a horror movie.<br /><br />\\"Jurassic Park III\\" simplified the plot, added new dinosaurs, and allowed the characters to develop more than \\"The Lost World.\\" The short length of the movie forced the movie to be simpler than the previous movie, and that simplicity makes for a good movie. The best new dinosaur in this movie had to be the pteranodons, though the spinosaur was great also. The characters in this movie generally acted as I would expect them to, and there were fewer outright acts of stupidity. Even the theft of a raptor egg was done in ignorance. B000000H3Z|5.0|If you want a good introduction to Sepultura, this isn't the best place to start(check out either Roots, their last good album, or Chaos A.D., which is one of the finest metal albums of all time). After you check those out, get Arise, which is also one of the best metal albums ever. If you enjoyed that,then run straight to your nearest C.D. store and buy this right away! Now, onto the album. While their next album,Arise, has a more Metallica and Iron Maiden inspired sound, this one is much more remenicent of Slayer or Morbid Angel. With that said, this album does NOT ever let up; it's just straight up, all out thrash/death metal, with some awesome solos and tight songwriting to boot. In fact, this album is so awesome, you wouldn't be crazy to say that it trumps even the Slayer classic \\"Reign in Blood\\", which to anyone who has heard that amazing album may seem like a bold statement. I argue that this very well might be the best metal album of all time, but if you just wanna rock out, then you definitly could do much worse. Very highly recommended to anyone who likes any form of metal.

B00005NVT1|5.0|First of all, so you know how good this CD is, I must admit that this is my first review in 3 years. With this album, I just had to make this step.    Let me start with saying that for the last 2 or 3 years I didn't lay my hands on a CD that would totally blow my mind. It has changed recently thanks to Alive 1997.    If you don't like electronic music that sounds a bit repetitive - this is not for you. But if you like it, or you are open minded and like to discover new grounds - give it a try (you won't regret). The only thing you should do before buying this live album is buying HOMEWORK by Daft Punk or at least listening to Da Funk, Rollin&Scratchin and Alive. Homework is their first and in my opinion best effort (only minority prefers Discovery I guess). When you will be totally fed up with the tracks like Da Funk, Rollin&Scratchin and Alive (if it's possible) turn on this live album. It is by far the best live recording I have ever heard. There is only one track on the whole CD (which in my opinion is good, because it stops you from messing around with this 45-minute masterpiece) which contains big parts of the songs I mentioned before. I had to take my jaw back from the floor after the first listen. Too bad I missed it 5 long years ago, when it was released. And when you think it's great after 10-15 minutes it gets even better.    I had the oportunity to see The Prodigy and The Chemical Brothers which was a stunning experience for me (too bad they didn't record any of their shows to make an LP), but after listening to this CD by Daft Punk I can say that I was also on Le Daft Punk gig. This album is so real, that everytime you listen to it, your legs and hands won't stop moving, and you feel like you are there listening to them live.    And I'm not even a big fan of DP. I think that every next album is worse from the previous one (only my humble opinion), but fortunately for me this one contains only songs from their first effort. The songs on this live set change into something you have never heard before - but you really love it (of course if Homework is the thing that moves you). There are so many unsuspected changes in tempo, volume etc.    When I heard this CD for the first time I decided that I have to see them live as soon as possible. After a while I discovered that they probably don't play shows like this anymore (after all so much has happened in their career since 1997).     It has only one disadvantage... it's way too short, it's not the whole gig, instead it fades out during alive and you only wish it would last forever...
B000024D4R|5.0|As far as my opinion goes this is my favorite Pink Floyd album. I am a huge fan and like all their music but this one is just amazing. It also seems unfair how under appreciated this album is. It may not have that one huge hit as some of the other albums had, but this one is classic Floyd. Must have for any fan of classic rock music.
0618551050|5.0|This is an extremely fine book.  Mr. Smolin gives an overview of twentieth century physics and explains developments in both string theory and quantum gravity (along with some other concepts that have not been popularized).  He does a nice job of exposing groupthink in academic physics departments and he seeks an environment where free-thinkers and seers are encouraged and rewarded instead of promoting another five hundred un-inventive number-crunchers. <br /> <br />Cheers and kudos for Mr. Smolin!  This groupthink seems as bad in academia as it is in the business world.   <br /> <br />And more cheers for Mr. Smolin encouraging significantly more study regarding the foundations of quantum theory and relativity!  I went to bed last night thinking about these foundations, trying to understand both relativity and quantum theory at the most fundamental level.  As my head hit the pillow, I thought... <br /> <br />Question:  How is it that relativity is a classical, continuous and causative concept while quantum mechanics is discrete and probabilistic?   <br /> <br />Potential Answer:  Space is an emergent phenomena resulting from a probabilistic mathematical construct contained within the sub-quantum level.  When the probabilities sum to one, a node of spacetime emerges.  These nodes are one Planck-length apart and spacetime only appears continuous because our present mathematical constructs don't allow us to penetrate further (than the Planck-length).  The key here is that seemingly causative continuity EMERGES from discreteness and, ultimately, probability.  If we could see the sub-quantum smaller than the Planck-length, we might even see the process of node formation as probability approaches one.  In effect, the birth of space (or a space-node) itself. <br /> <br />If true, mathematics or statistics becomes more primary than space itself.  And if true, this implies that math or statistics is more primary than geometry.   <br /> <br />Okay, now what about `time'? <br/> <br />Time is a classical and continuous concept.  We can measure time in various ways, such as the `time' it takes for a photon to transverse some distance (such as an atom).  But we are ultimately measuring change when we do this.  The photon was at point A when we started and now it is a point B.  The position has changed.  So time really has meaning only when something has changed, and by measuring this change, time can be thought of as geometric or spatial.  (Remember now that geometry is not primary...)  And, of course, changes are `caused' (and explained in the classical, continuous and causative concepts imbedded in relativity).  The key here, however, is that without change, what are we measuring with regard to the classical concept of `time'?  The answer is nothing.  Time does not occur because nothing has changed.  We have a still photograph or one frame instead of a movie.  <br /> <br />So time is also an emergent phenomena, along with space (and geometry).  Until a node of special fabric is formed, there is no time because there is no space, because without space... nothing can change.  Until a space-node is formed, we only have the possibility of space.  (We only have statistics.)  Once a node is formed, we have the reality and geometry of space.  And eventually... causation and change. <br /> <br />Thus, space and time are emergent phenomena.  In sum, we can say that relativity emerges from the sub-quantum, and geometry emerges from statistics.    <br /> <br />So there you have it... that's when I fell to sleep.  I think I may have read somewhere, and it might have been Roger Penrose, who said that mathematics was invented or formed to explain geometry...a way of understanding our physical world.  I believe it is ironic that it may indeed be the other way around, and that geometry is not primary at all, as explained above.  After all, geometry makes no sense at all at a sub-quantum level smaller than a Planck-length.   <br /> <br />So, in the beginning there is just an idea, an abstraction.  Possibility. <br /> <br />Maybe more people should be studying statistics in high school instead of geometry.      <br />

B0006GAOJA|3.0|I made it 20-something years without seeing this film, and I finally caved and bought it on the cheap. It is filmed in black and white, and the visual style is solid.  The boxing scenes (and one of my biggest disappointments is that there aren't enough of them) are very exciting.  Although I have no idea if this played a part in Scorcese's decision to film in b&w, I suspect that if it were in color the boxing would have been too gruesome for most viewers.  LaMotta is basically squirting fluid all over the place in his last fight against Sugar Ray.<br /><br />In addition to covering LaMotta's career, the film follows his relationship with his brother, Joey, and his wife.  His levels of jealousy regarding his wife border on the inconceivably insane, and consequently that entire dimension of the film is unbelievable.  Quite frankly, LaMotta would have to be mentally disabled to act that stupid.<br /><br />The film also suffers from a slow start.  We eventually do care about LaMotta, but it takes awhile.<br /><br />But ultimately, why do we really care?  We never see a single scene that shows us why he loves his wife, nor one that shows why his wife loves him.  They date, they fool around, they marry (in a montage), they fight, and then after all the bad times are apparently behind them she does something she should have done years ago.  Their relationship makes absolutely no sense.<br /><br />In the end, we see LaMotta (in a scene most younger viewers will think was lifted from the end of \\"Boogie Nights\\") quoting verbatim a lengthy monologue from a much better movie, \\"On the Waterfront\\".  That's a good point, I must admit... why didn't I spend the last 2 hours watching \\"On the Waterfront\\" instead?

B000002J1M|5.0|Having grown up in the 80's, I really didn't understand what this band had once been until I became reinterested in prog rock.  The first time I got into prog, in high school, I became fixated on Yes and Jethro Tull and ELP.  Then through happenstance I listened to \\"Red\\" by King Crimson while a grad student, and I soon found myself immersed in the genre for a second go-round.  It was only during this renewed fascination with prog rock that I really discovered Genesis as they had been, as they are on this album.<br /><br />There are clearly four *essential* Genesis albums from the Peter Gabriel era.  Among those four, I actually suggest that this one be the first album for a listener new to the music.  The side-long \\"Supper's Ready\\" is fairly similar to other prog rock of the era and makes this album the most familiar-sounding to fans of the genre.  Overall \\"Foxtrot\\" isn't as lyrically and thematically dense as the supposed magnum opus of the band, \\"The Lamb Lies Down on Broadway.\\"<br /><br />Musically, it's much closer to Tull than to King Crimson, despite my own and many other's references to Crimson when discussing Genesis.  Unlike King Crimson, Genesis' essential albums from this period (including \\"Foxtrot\\", of course) are more consistently good throughout the album.  King Crimson made only two albums that were consistently good throughout, \\"In the Court...\\" and \\"Red\\" (which sounds nothing like any other prog rock made, so isn't a good comparison.)  Genesis is lightyears ahead of \\"In the Court...\\", as it is also lightyears ahead of early ELP.<br /><br />Although they get 0% of the radioplay that ELP, Yes and Jethro Tull get, they are every bit as good.  Classic rock radio can completely overlook them, but if you like those other bands then you shouldn't make the same mistake.<br /><br />At the listed price of around $10, this is a very good buy.

B00005JLO2|4.0|This beautiful film is very complex, with a few flaws, but overall a good exploration of the concept of commitment.  <br /> <br />Whereas the plot requires that the script be spun around the concept of cowardice, the four feather insult, and the lengthy redemption - there is an underlying and subtle theme of commitment that rings very true. <br /> <br />Commitment itself is a complex emotion since commitment to one person or idea may compete with commitment to other folks or ideas. This is the dilema that faces handsome Harry Haversham, played well by the ever changing chameleon Heath Ledger. <br /> <br />Harry has made a decision to join the army due to family commitments, specifically his father who is a general. He has made commitments to his buddies, his fellow soldiers. Thi is especially true for his commitment to his best friend, Jack Durrance (played beautifully by Wes Bentley). He has made commitments to his young fiance, Ethne Eustace, played by Kate Hudson. And he has commitments to himself, for he never wished to become a soldier and go to war. A British offensive in the Sudan is the catalyst for Harry to resign his commission as an officer in the army and leave the armed services. <br /> <br />Harry decides to honor the commitment to himself, imagining that his relationship with Ethne will not change. Yet she is deeply impacted and can not imagine their life together if they are social outcasts.  <br /> <br />And so, by honoring his commitment to himself, Harry does not honor his commitment to Queen and country, to his father, to his fiance, and to his buddies. After the fellows become fully sunk in the wasp nest of the Sudan, Harry becomes greatly concerned at the report of the high number of deaths of British soldiers. He makes his way to the Sudan to save and protect his buddies and redeem himself in the eyes of others. <br /> <br />During this dramatic struggle Harry undergoes some of the trials and tribulations of the hero, many of which are explained in the writings of Joseph Campbell. For example, in many myths regarding heroes, the hero shows kindness to a lesser being and in turn is rewarded. Harry shows kindness to an African tribal princess who spares his life when her tribesman kills the camel train leader.  <br /> <br />The struggles intensify as Harry becomes an observant pawn in a strategic struggle between Sudanese Islamic insurgents and British imperial troops. <br /> <br />At this point he meets Abu Fatma, played exceptionally well by Djimon Hounsou. Djimon is an absolute mountain of muscle, a giant imposing character. Here the film becomes Jungian for in many ways Abu is Harry's shadow, the confrontation with the dark side of the self which brings about a stronger integrated personality. In classic Jungian theory, the Shadow is at first feared,and then becomes a guide into deeper feelings, and finally is integrated into the personality resulting in a stronger character with greater insight and compassion. This is exactly what happens in this partnership between Harry and Abu. <br /> <br />In the end, Harry undertakes feats of incredible bravery and daring. He redeems himself in the eyes of those who saw him as a coward. He does this not only through brave acts but by integration of competing forces within his personality. Harry emerges a far more centered man after his encounter in the desert with his shadow. <br /> <br />There are other well developed sub-themes such as Jack Durrance's heroism and sacrifice first of his eyes and then of his relationship with Ethne.  <br /> <br />The film ends with a fine speech by Jack Durrance about commitment to an abstract Queen and country as compared to commitment to the flesh and blood concrete reality of those comrades with whom we have bonded. And thus this parable tells us that our first commitment is to self, and then to those we love, but there is sometimes a steep price to pay for our commitments. <br /> <br />The grand sweeping palaces of England and the desolate prisons hidden in  African deserts offer vastly different views of the world of the British Empire. The film takes us on a grand journey of the eyes and of the character.
B00007146Y|4.0|Based upon the wonderful, well-written novel \\"Red Dragon\\" by Thomas Harris, this is a superior and chilling thriller. Grim and gripping, it features Edward Norton in the role of troubled, retired FBI agent, Will Graham, who is called back to service in order to track down a bizarre serial killer, known as the \\"Tooth Fairy\\". It appears that Graham has the uncanny ability to get into a killer's mindset and figure out what his next move might be. It is as if he and the killer become one. In his preparation for this, Graham even consults the imprisoned Hannibal Lecter (yes, THE Hannibal Lecter), deliciously played by Anthony Hopkins. Unfortunately for Graham, Hannibal has not forgotten that Graham was responsible for his changed circumstances.<br /><br />It is Hannibal Lecter, after all, who was the catalyst for Will Graham's retirement. The viewer is treated to scenes of Lecter's life, before he was revealed to be Hannibal the Cannibal, one of the sickest serial killers ever to strike. The viewer sees the renowned psychiatrist in his milieu as an erudite, cultured, and wealthy patron of the arts. A noted gourmand, Dr. Lecter liked nothing better than to give intimate dinner parties for the favored few. Of course, some of the ingredients used for his dinners were best left unsaid. It was nice to see the always excellent John Rubenstein in the small role of a dinner guest, heaping accolades upon Hannibal for his dinner parties.<br /><br />The movie is compelling and, at all times, gripping. Anthony Hopkins reprises his career defining role and steals the show (Really, Hannibal Lecter has become all but a cottage industry for him!). With a twinkle in his eye, he is, in his low key way, deliciously malevolent. Edward Norton, one of the best young actors around, gives a decent and sensitive portrayal of Will Graham, the angst ridden former FBI agent and profiler, but lacks the grittiness and hard-edged veneer that the role really demands. He also simply looks too young and soft for the role. Ralph Fiennes gives a fine performance as the tormented Francis Dolarhyde, but his portrayal is hampered by the fact that too little is revealed in the film about what makes him tick.<br /><br />Emily Watson affectingly plays a blind woman who becomes romantically involved with Francis Dolarhyde. It is her involvement with him that helps bring the film to its stunning conclusion. Moreover, Ms. Watson is a wonderfully talented British actress who manages to get her American accent down pat. Good performances by Harvey Keitel, as Graham's former boss, and Mary Louise Parker, as Graham's wife, round out this fine, ensemble cast.<br /><br />This film is a taut, unnerving psychological thriller that is subject to comparison to its 1986 predecessor \\"Manhunter. Having seen both, I call it a draw. This current version had a bigger budget, so obviously it has better production values. Also, the opening scenes in the current version are more interesting than those in the 1986 one. Music, however, was used to much better effect in the earlier version. Moreover, the final scenes in the earlier version were much better than in this later version, as they were much more suspenseful. Both films, however, are well worth watching. Do yourself a favor and view both. Then, judge for yourself.soft for the role. It is her involvement with him that helps bring the film to its stunning conclusion. Moreover, Ms. Watson is a wonderfully talented British actress who manages to get her American accent down pat. Good performances by Harvey Keitel, as Graham's former boss, and Mary Louise Parker, as Graham's wife, round out this fine, ensemble cast.<br /><br />This film is a taut, unnerving psychological thriller that is subject to comparison to its 1986 predecessor \\"Manhunter. Having seen both, I call it a draw. This current version had a bigger budget, so obviously it has better production values. Also, the opening scenes in the current version are more interesting than those in the 1986 one. Music, however, was used to much better effect in the earlier version. Moreover, the final scenes in the earlier version were much better than in this later version, as they were much more suspenseful. Both films, however, are well worth watching. Do yourself a favor and view both. Then, judge for yourself.

B000H7JD4K|5.0|Like death and taxes, the only thing constant is the 'refusal to change with the trends' sound of Maiden. This is without a doubt their most progressive sounding album since the mid-80's. I have this album for over two weeks now and it has grown on me to the point where i can actually recognize each song based on a riff or a galloping bass line or guitar rhythm that comes up. Does that ever happen in 'metal' albums these days? The sound is raw and more angrier and grittier than the previous two revamped 6-man line-up releases. Brave New World was good . Dance of death, well except for Paschendale and Rainmaker, the less said about it the better. <br />I always felt it was more of a filler release. But this, this is what they all got back together to make. Bruce actually sounds so different on the first track i was wondering what happened to the air-raid siren, it is a typical mid-tempo album opener still not quite on par with 'The wicker man' but this is more melodic.  <br />Then comes 'These colors dont run' and you know that you are in for something different. Its all there the time changes, the galloping sound and you can actually make out the three different guitars. The album has not been mastered, to heck with it , the whole thing has a vibrant live feel to it. Its even got the 'woo hoo hoo hoo's ' which some people hate but i absolutely love it.  <br />Most of the songs here have the typical slow start and then Bruce airing his lungs out and the three guitar attack kicking in . People say thats what they always do. Well yes but who else does it better? thats why we keep coming back for more Maiden. Maiden have never written a song like 'Brighter than a Thousand Suns' ya sure there have been epics but this one sounds dark and angry like something straight off a Dickinson solo album from the late nineties.'For the greater good of God' has lyrics that make you think. Nicko's snare drum has a sound that i never heard in the last couple of albums. Bruce doesnt sound a day older than he did in the 80's and you know that no one else can ever sing these songs, they are tailor made for him.  <br />Be warned that if you dont like those long epics (this record is filled with them) and just want to head bang for a few minutes then this album is not for you and u'r better off buying the new Slayer record instead. Otherwise give this a couple of spins and i bet by the third time u say \\"man how did i miss this part in the song before\\" . The album is alike a multilayered cake and it gets better as you go deeper with it and find new things.  <br />I could do a track by track but you can find that in other reviews. This is just meant to be another metal fan's humble opinion. Maiden in the new millenium is sounding great with six men on top of their game with their ego's aside. I've heard 12 new albums in the past two weeks but this has become a staple in my daily diet. This album will be hailed as a new classic by the end of the year and Maiden will continue selling out arenas the world over and someday the people at Ozzfest will learn. UP THE IRONS!!!
B000002KKS|5.0|Indeed, at the dawn of the 80's Black Sabbath, fronted by former Rainbow vocalist Ronnie James Dio, seemed to be hinting the answer to this eternal question by releasing \\"Heaven & Hell\\". After surviving a string of rough years and (at least) a couple of uneven albums, Sabbath parted ways with original singer Ozzy Osbourne.<br /><br />Let's stop being fanatics for a moment and analyze things in their true dimension, if you please: I love Ozzy, both with Sabbath and solo, but the guy IS NOT a singer! He got the gig in Sabbath because he was the only soul who could afford the P.A system and the microphone required to sing. This is not fiction, this is a historical fact, and Ozzy has openly admitted as much! Of course, that was part of his charm: he was a John Doe who became a big shot, and even though he couldn't sing, he was charismatic and lovable, and became a fundamental part of Sabbath's sound and success.<br /><br />For whatever reason(s), this success story came to an abrupt halt at the end of the \\"Never say Die\\" tour. Regardless of the circumstances, Ozzy was gone. Enter Ronnie James Dio: a TRUE vocalist. He came aboard and Sabbath regained their focus, which was sorely missing in albums such as \\"Sabbotage\\", \\"Technical Ecstasy\\" and above all, \\"Never Say Die\\", which featured some great songs, but were for the most part a dissapointment for the fans AND the band alike (again, this is not fiction: all of the members of the band have said as much, including Ozzy).<br /><br />Oddly enough, I was \\"introduced\\" to this album and this lineup of Sabbath basically by accident: after discovering Sabbath via a Greatest Hits tape that I borrowed from a friend, I decided to get some of their music. Of course, that tape consisted of only Ozzy-era songs. I was always reading magazines, so I knew about Dio replacing Ozzy, but I didn't know Dio's music either! So, after searching high and low (at that time, it wasn't easy to get music from \\"old bands\\" in my country...), I got \\"Paranoid\\"; then, the only other record I could find was \\"Heaven and Hell\\". So, hesitantly, I got it and...my musical life was changed forever!!<br /><br />Ronnie James Dio became my biggest influence! He is, as far as I'm concerned, THE BEST hard rock vocalist EVER! I recognized the sound of the band, it was Sabbath for sure, but it was a different, leaner, meaner Sabbath! The funny thing is that the band decided not to go back to its traditional Ozzy-era sound, which relied heavily on epic songs such as \\"War Pigs\\", \\"Iron Man\\", \\"Black Sabbath\\", etc. Instead, Sabbath forged ahead in a new direction, which retained the identity traits of the band's sound, but also presented something new. The songs are more straight forward, in the vein of songs such as \\"Never Say Die\\" and \\"Rock n' Roll Doctor\\", as opposed to being the typical 7 minute riff-fest of yore.<br /><br />This is demonstrated with the opening track, the brutal \\"Neon Knights\\": the moment you hear that riff, YOU KNOW that Sabbath is back with a vengeance! This is also true for other awesome tracks such \\"Lady Evil\\", \\"Wishing Well\\", \\"Die Young\\" and \\"Walk Away\\", all of them gems in their own right. Then you have 3 more songs that, while retaining some of the grand epic overtones that Sabbath became famous for, clearly indicate an evolution towards new sonic territories: \\"Children of the Sea\\" is a moody trip that starts quietly and then slams you in the head; \\"Lonely is the Word\\" is the magnificent, epic showcase of Tony Iommi's playing that closes the album (somewhat reminiscent of songs like \\"Dirty Women\\"); and above all, the title track, \\"Heaven and Hell\\", a true rock masterpiece. I won't waste any time writing about it, as I believe that it is unnecessary, and no matter what I say, it wouldn't do justice to the song.<br /><br />It's very difficult for me to talk about favorite tracks, since I truly believe that each and every one is a highlight, but I would have to say that the ones that had the biggest impact on me at a first listen were \\"Neon Knights\\", \\"Children of the Sea\\", \\"Lady Evil\\", \\"Heaven and Hell\\" and \\"Wishing Well\\".<br /><br />So, essentially, this is it: \\"Heaven and Hell\\" is, without a doubt, one of the few undisputed rock jewels of all time. If you don't have it, for whatever reason, you don't know what you've been missing! Do yourself a favor: Forget about all the preconceptions you might have about this lineup of the band and get this CD. NOW!\\"Children of the Sea\\", \\"Lady Evil\\", \\"Heaven and Hell\\" and \\"Wishing Well\\".     So, essentially, this is it: \\"Heaven and Hell\\" is, without a doubt, one of the few undisputed rock jewels of all time. If you don't have it, for whatever reason, you don't know what you've been missing! Do yourself a favor: Forget about all the preconceptions you might have about this lineup of the band and get this CD. NOW!

The only difference is that, this time around, they are trying to make the music more accessible to the masses.  Does it work?  I think so, yeah.  The title song has some of the best musical parts I've ever heard, and the vocal melody is pretty decent as well.  That song, along with \\"the endless enigma (part one)\\" are really interesting compositions.  The musical ideas keep shifting around, and I like it a lot.  Even though I'm past my progressive rock phase, I STILL like coming back to this album and absorbing those keyboards and drum tricks.   <br /> <br />The whole album reminds me of church, and looking up at those colored windows (I don't know what you call those windows).  Many ELP songs remind me of either the Washington Monument, church or the Philadelphia mint. Everyone is surprised, when she suddenly shines with her singing, when before she had just been part of the background. B00004ZBLD|3.0|Vivaldi might have composed this oratorio with the celestial and the majestic in mind.<br /><br />Breaking with tradition, even the sinfonia is grandiose and pompous. Not surprisingly, it is borrowed from the first and second movements of concerto grosso con molti strumenti that portends something big is about to happen.<br /><br />Noteworthy are performances by Magdalena Kozena, and Marina Comparato.<br /><br />Juditha Triumphans treasures one of Vivaldi's most beautiful gems and presto arias di furie, Armatae Face Et Anguibus. Taking the task of singing this battle cry, Marina Comparato met and overcame the high standard previously set by Cecilia Bartoli. While Bartoli immersed her character in incontrollable rage and furious vengeance, Comparato turned a spin and sank hers in fear and despair at the death of Holofernes. Her melisma in singing the second vocal run of the aria conveys the vulnerability and anguish of Vagaus, the eunuch, at the death of his beloved master. Both voices and coloraturas are beautiful in conveying different psyches of the same character. What a difference an opera makes for Marina Comparato! Her brilliance was very visible in Il Giustino, but her virtuosity is established here.<br /><br />Magdalena Kozena simply sparkles in her role of Juditha, and singing of the virtuoso arias \\"Veni, Veni, Me Sequere Fidu\\", and \\"Agitata Infidu Flatu\\".

0812550706|4.0|I found Ender's Game an exhilarating ride of a book, one that kept me pressing ahead chapter by chapter to see what would be revealed next, what would happen to Ender. Card does an excellent job setting a world that is normal enough to create empathy with the characters, yet strange enough to give a sense of unease to the reader. Immediately Ender became the character to cheer for because he is put through such abuse. His brother and sister initially seem to be opposites, but this changes as the story moves along.<br /><br /> Ender's sister, Valentine, vacillates morally throughout the book between the poles of \\"good\\" Ender and \\"bad\\" Peter, though these designations are much harder to deal with at the end when Peter is the herald of world peace and Ender is . . . not. I was unsatisfied with the development of Peter within the story (why did he change?) but Valentine was well fleshed out. Her ideas of emotional control over those around her are quite interesting and prove to be true.<br /><br /> The philosophy of Ender's Game is certainly attractive and in the same vein of much science fiction. Humanity can and will accomplish whatever it sets its mind to, including colonize the stars, as long as it can overcome the evil within itself. I found that Card does not overdo his insertion of philosophy into the novel at the cost of story. Masterfully, Card uses the standards of this genre to bring out some hard questions about evil's role within each human, ends justifying the means, and the decisions of popular opinion or secret power.<br /><br />Favorite quotes:<br /><br /> \\"Humanity does not ask us to be happy. It merely asks us to be brilliant on its behalf. Survival first, then happiness as we can manage it.\\"<br /><br />\\"Welcome to the human race. Nobody controls his own life, Ender. The best you can do is choose to be controlled by good people, by people who love you.\\"

There is so much extra footage on the DVD that is seems like Spinal Tap 2.   <br /> <br />The extras are as good as the original movie. I couldn't stop laughing when the band goes to the zoo and near the chimps cage when they are talking their usual ridiculous lines they say things like \\"'..chimps can't talk but can use computers..\\" and stuff. B0000549B0|5.0|For haven's sake, let him be \\"crazy\\" and pleasant, don't make him \\"perfectly normal\\" and nasty!      I was led to believe that Harvey is a movie  about a drunk who sees a hallucination due to his excesses drinking. As a matter of  fact that is  not the case. Elwood P. Dowd (Jimmy Stewart) is a carefree philanthropist. His big smile is contagious and his selflessness and generosity are adorable. To him, every day is beautiful and every fellow human is important.  If you are fortunate to meet Elwood,  he'd buy you a drink or two and invite you for dinner at his home. No matter what the circumstances, at least he'll give you one of his cards (so you can always reach him) and a warm  compliment, and a peace of his golden heart.     Elwood shares his home with his sister Veta Louise (Josephine Hull), her daughter and Harvey, 6-foot tall rabbit, that only he can see. Harvey is Elwood's best friend and constant companion. Unfortunately, Elwood's obsession with his imaginary friend interferes with Veta's plans to marry off her daughter and she decides to put him in a mental hospital. Then a hilarious mix up occurs and Veta finds herself committed instead.  It is now up to Elwood and Harvey to sort the mess out and Veta needs to make a decision -does she want her brother to change and become \\"normal and nasty\\" or does she prefer him the way he is, loving, caring and generous. And what about Harvey? Well, he is part of the dilemma.    There are twists and turns in this much loved classic. Although a comedy, there is a lot of drama and wisdom in it and an important message delivered with refreshing sense of humour. The performances are brilliant, all of the cast play their hearts out. Josephine Hull is fantastic and she rightly deserves her Oscar for this performance but the show belongs to the ever-captivating Jimmy Stewart, who in my opinion was robbed again on the Academy Awards night. Lets not forget Harvey, he is brilliant too. If you've had trouble seeing him throughoutthe show, you can't miss him at the end. Trust me, he was there and I saw him, 6'8 foot tall, white rabbit! He will take you to a better world, where all days are beautiful and everybody is important and appreciated.     The DVD transfer is good quality with clear sound and picture in 4:3 ratio. There is a theatrical trailer and a special introduction by Jimmy Stewart, which was recorded in 1990. Harvey is a fabulous movie, one that simply  cannot be made nowadays.  The screen play is based on a Pulitzer Prize-winning play by Mary Chase and with one of Jimmy Stewart's finest performances, it is a jewel to be enjoyed and treasured forever!
B001S86J2Q|1.0|When Grease was re-released to theaters in 1998, Paramount inexplicably remixed the soundtrack. There seems to be no good reason for this, but it was during a time when \\"special edition\\" releases were constantly messing with the original version of films. Unfortunately, there are numerous errors and changes in the remix. Some are downright inexcusable, like percussion and background vocals in the wrong place, bad music edits and even background vocals out of sync during You're the One That I Want. Foley and dialog balances are off throughout. It's a mess.<br /><br />Despite the fact that fans have been complaining for years, Paramount included only this remix on the 2 DVD versions they released. I had assumed they would finally include the original soundtrack on the blu ray, but they are STILL only using the botched remix. This is unbelievable. Including the far superior original soundtrack would cost them virtually nothing, and yet they continue to disrespect a popular classic movie and it fans, despite being repeatedly made aware of the problem. I bought the first 2 DVD editions, but refuse to buy a blu ray until they fix the soundtrack.<br /><br />The only way to hear the original, correct soundtrack is on pre-1998 VHS and laserdisc copies. I guess ignorance is bliss, and if you don't know what you are missing it won't bother you, but I can't stand to watch the movie with the remix.

006056251X|4.0|The second book in Lisa Kleypas' Wallflower series, It Happened One Autumn, ended with shy, virginal Evangeline Jenner making an outrageous proposal to infamous rake and seducer of innocents, Sebastian, Lord St. Vincent.  To escape her overbearing and abusive relatives, Evie asked Sebastian to join her in a marriage of convenience that would be mutually beneficial; the marriage would protect her from her relatives' plotting while her dowry and inheritance would revive his dwindling fortune.  So the two embark on what is supposed to be a marriage in name only. Evie agrees to sleep with Sebastian once, to make the marriage legal, but never again so as not to lose her heart to him.  They run off to Gretna Green to begin a life as husband and wife.<br /><br />This was by far my favorite book in the Wallflower series.  Kleypas found a formula that works this time and I actually enjoyed both the hero and the heroine.  Usually in Regency romances it's one or the other for me.  Sebastian adhered perfectly to the adage that reformed rakes make the best husbands with his constant doting on Evie, brash fits of jealousy, and reluctance to surrender his heart.  And once Evie managed to climb out of her fearful shell and take back control of her life, she became a new, stronger person who was a joy to read about.  I was angry when this book ended since it was in such stark contrast to the disappointing story in It Happened One Autumn.  I can only hope that the final book in the Wallflower series, Scandal in Spring, can keep up the momentum that this book has created for the series.

I've since obtained a copy of \\"The Downward Spiral\\", and while I find it to be fascinating--not to mention obnoxious at times--I have to admit that, at age 41, I prefer \\"With Teeth\\", which is more advanced both lyrically and musically.  Mr. Reznor's prodigious anger has thankfully been somewhat tempered by his new-found penchant for intelligent reflection and, yes, emotional growth. That's not to say that he's gotten boring.  His innate talent precludes that.  There are some genuinely beautiful melodies here to go along with his improved singing voice, but--not to worry--there's also the residual self-hatred, self-absorption, and loathing for existence shared by all nihilists.  I like to think that I have a little man that lives inside of me.  His name is Trent Reznor.

Bruises, swollen eyes, broken teeth and cut lips are trophies. Another aspect of the movie is idol worship. I don't care about the \\"anamorphic\\" widescreen; when I put the DVD in my DVD player, it works. I don't care about Dolby 5.1; the sound is how I remember seeing it as a 7 year-old. The picture isn't crystal clear, but I say, so what? It is nearly a 30-year old film, and if you want crystal clear picture, watch the 2004 version instead. That's what it's there for. I happen to appreciate a film that doesn't quite have razor-sharp clarity. It lends a bit of nostalgic value. 'Star Wars' doesn't have to look brand new to me, because it isn't brand new. I find it wonderful to finally have a DVD version of the Original Trilogy, no matter if it lacked in the restoration process. Some viewers, like myself, prefer the worn-in feel. I love it.

The events are narrated by Death, who is so intrigued by Liesl's life that he brings her a book himself. <br /> <br />This story shows how patient love can heal a damaged spirit and that the best gifts don't cost any money. One could count my achievements with one hand. <br /> <br />Then I found Millionaire. <br /> <br />As the title suggests, this is not a book about methods and schemes for making millions.  It is about the average Joe you already know.  It is about the guy next door who is sitting on a million dollars, and the discipline, genius, and sacrifices he needed to get there. <br /> <br />Thomas J. Stanley debunks the aristocracy myth with this statistic from his book: 80% of all Americans with a net worth of at least $1,000,000 are first-generation millionaires.  Armed with this newfound knowledge, he actually shows you how to become one of these 80%.  He explains the methodical process necessary to become a millionaire.  This book encourages you to cut out the excess in your life and become a smart saver and investor.  It can show you the path to self-discipline, and helps to reorient your priorities.  I recommend this book to any one high school age and up. <br /> <br />If you are looking for stock tips, hedge funds, or venture capital schemes, get a grip. B0000DD7LB|4.0|In the Zone marks a breakthrough in pop music as the bubblegum pop trend of the late 90s began to transition into electro-hip hop-(bubblegum)-pop.  Britney Spears, N'Sync, and Christina Aguilera were all growing up and ready to break out into new areas of the pop landscape.    In the Zone represents Britney Spears transition into adulthood.  It's a mistake to think the lyrics would be any less sexualized, this is pop music we are talking about.  But Britney has grown as an artist.  Her third album, Britney, is a pinnacle of the bubblegum pop movement, one of the most coherent bubblegum albums with minimal filler.  For In the Zone, she took a step away from being manufactured by stepping into the executive producer's chair and working with a revolving door of producers from R. Kelly to Moby plus a bevy of lesser known producers popular on the club circuit.  The result: Britney expanding her vocal versatility as she explores different pop sounds.    The strongest songs are when she moves towards electro-pop trance.  The pairings of Breathe on Me and Touch of My Hand puts her in Kylie Minogue land, and puts her breathy and husky vocals in a context that feels truly artistic.  They maximize the potential of her voice.  The stripped down ballad, Everytime, dares to put her vocals in a showcase, and it works, revealing an aching vulnerability.  Britney never may have had pitch range, but her voice strikes an emotional chord that not even the screaming Aguilera can GENUINELY reach.    The electro-pop reaches its peak with Toxic.  The acid violins on that song are now iconic and instantly recognizeble.  Even the video, an artistically campy tribute to Jennifer Garner's Alias, is a work of art.    The trifecta of Outrageous, Showdown, and I've Got that (Boom Boom) exemplify pop's infusion with hip hop to abandon its goody goody bubble gum roots.  The Outrageous Tribal Remix is better than the original but its fun.  Showdown reaches back to the Breathe Heavy Sing-Talk of Boys, and Boom Boom with the Ying Yang twins is a great club song with its thumping base.  However, Brave New Girl recalls the bubblegum of the Britney album, a fun upbeat song about fresh starts.    When the album came out, it was criticized for not being a coherent sounding album.  It wasn't supposed to be.  The acoustic Me Against the Music, dance Breathe on Me, and others proved that the album was about Britney exploring the sonic landscape.  At the time it was new for mainstream pop to go this direction.  Now, everyone accepts it.  Beyonce, Usher, and Adam Lambert have utilized the same cover-all-genres approaches.    Unfortunately, this is also the phase of Britney's life where she began to downfall--K Fed, shaved head, and all.  Britney was beginning to finally take the dance music that were just bonus tracks or B-Sides (I highly recommend Before the Goodbye, When I found You, I Run Away) into the main tracks of her album and hence push it more into the mainstream.  Unfortunately, with her breakdown, the people around her once again took full control of her career, which was probably also aided by weak album sales, and Britney lost her Exec Producer credit on Blackout.      I love Blackout, and Circus is a return to a \\"Britney\\" sound, but I can't help but wonder what would have happened if In the Zone had gone well and Britney was allowed even more freedom post-In the Zone.  But I just might found out.  Reports suggest that Britney will be seriously pushing the edges of pop on her next album (thank you for the push Lady Gaga).  Although, Britney shouldn't have needed the advent of Gaga to make her label finally take a chance on artistry, because Britney always had the goods to deliver--In the Zone proved that.

B000002JSP|3.0|Due to Jimmy Page and John Bonham chasing the tail of the drug dragon and Robert Plant's vocal chords being frayed - a portion of In Through The Out Door was recorded in a studio used by vocal group ABBA - it was up to bassist/keyboard player John Paul Jones to hold the pieces of the band together for the \\"comeback\\" album that was released in the summer of 1979.<br /><br />The original album featured six different inner sleeves, which when brushed over with water, would become fully colored. The \\"cover\\" was made to look like a brown paper bag.<br /><br />The band - unlike The Rolling Stones and The Who - was not known to bring a lot of material into the studio. Not only was that brought out in the previous weak studio albums, Presence and the double-set, Physical Graffiti, but fully demonstrated in Coda, a release of odds-and-ends that was better left on studio tapes, with three of the cuts not making it on In Through The Out Door.<br /><br />Jones co-wrote six of the seven cuts and flexes his artistic skill on Carouselambra, which clocks in at nearly eleven minutes. The CD kicks off on familiar territory, In The Evening, with Bonham's strongest drumming and Page ripping into a solo midway through the song.<br /><br />It is a mixed bag after the two cuts. The band travels over the same turf in Fool In The Rain and I'm Gonna Crawl. The rave-up Hot Dog and AOR sound of All My Love are interesting, but cannot carry the CD to the artistic heights found in the initial four studio releases.<br /><br />But in a summer where punk still showed signs of life, the album debuted on the Billboard chart at number one.<br /><br />In Through The Out Door was slated for release before the Knebworth Festival tour dates, but hit the store shelves slightly after the critically-acclaimed gigs. There were numerous bootleg releases of the Knebworth concerts and fans can sometimes hear the complete show on radio stations with \\"classic rock\\" formats.<br /><br />A highly-anticipated U.S. tour was slated for 1980, but the death of Bonham led to the band disbanding.<br /><br />Jones has taken a lot of flack for his work on the album. Plant and Page have left him dangling alone for the critics to take the brunt of the criticism over the years. Jones has been basically been persona non grata with his former bandmates.<br /><br />Jones was handed the task by default. And he ultimately demonstrated a professionalism that is hardly seen on stage in the rock industry.ipated U.S. tour was slated for 1980, but the death of Bonham led to the band disbanding. <br /> <br />Jones has taken a lot of flack for his work on the album. I have not wavered from that opinion over the years.<br /><br />Without the guidance of producer Bob Ezrin and guitarist David Gilmour, who kept Waters in check while developing elements of The Wall during the recording process, the path was clear for his self-indulgence to take center stage. It is Pink Floyd in name only, with Waters supported by a number of guest musicians.<br /><br />Keyboardist Richard Wright was told by Waters that he was sacked before The Wall tour, hence he does not appear on the album. It is questionable how much studio time was clocked by Gilmour or drummer Nick Mason.<br /><br />Waters decries the use of war as a tool by governments. He juxtaposes the the death of his father in the battle of Anzio in World War II with the Falkland Islands War and the Cold War hysteria that was gripping the superpowers in the early 1980s. New production techniques made for better sound quality on vinyl.<br /><br />But it fails on many levels because Waters is screeching to himself. It is a great representation of what happens to a band that fails to have the checks and balances of developing ideas into music.<br /><br />At this point in time, Waters delivered his final cut on many levels.

1592400876|5.0|It's easy to see how the book's breezy run through \\"the notations of music of the spoken language\\" has made it a bestseller. It's a memorable reminder of the purpose of punctuation in the first place: to clarify syntax and meaning. Ms. Truss does that with lan! <br /> <br />From humorous examples of the daily bugaboos that make email unreadable (\\"let me know if your coming to lunch\\" and \\"are their any left?\\" were recently in my email) to the weightier influence of comma placement (Jesus to thief on the cross: \\"and He said unto him, today thou shalt be with me in paradise\\" or was it \\"and He said unto him today, thou shalt be with me in paradise\\" in which the latter leaves a huge gap for purgatory) the author provides a neat understanding of common - and not so common - grammar rules without any sense of reading a rule book. <br /> <br />With a dash of history, gracious pauses for appreciation of growth and flexibility in language, and a lot of good romping pillow fight fun you will get to the end of the book before you are ready. B00005JP87|3.0|This is a film that offers so much silliness and hooey that I just couldn't buy in. I would have loved to see real illusions performed, rather than the cgi nonsense seen here. Watching a movie about magic, I'd much prefer to see David Blaine-like illusions rather than these hopelessly physics and reason-defying jokes. And having a book with Michaelangelo-like diagrams in it showing how the trick is built makes no difference. They are stupid and irritating.<br /><br />Many have pointed out how lovely this film is. That it certainly is. It looks great, and I never grew tired of the soft focus and sepia haze. Costumes, swords, helmets, trains, stage lighting, carriages all looked superlative. But look only goes so far. Phillip Glass has indeed cannibalized his previous work, though at least the score was not annoying. And we can debate whether this or that actor was good or bad. For my taste, Edward Norton was just too cold and cerebral; why would this woman love him? But generally I accepted the performances.<br /><br />No, a film like this lives or dies on plot, and if anyone was surprised by the ending, they must have been sleeping. I too was hoping some better illusion was impending, one that hadn't been telgraphed, telephoned, billboarded, and announced in any number of ways. But no, the ending we all thought was coming came chugging in, right on schedule, with all the remarkable coincidences and unlikely events (good thing the Prince didn't drink just a bit more, or less, of that potion, and oh, the convenient Friar Lawrence magic worked a little better here than for Romeo and Juliet) tidily cleaned up in fast-forward.<br /><br />So a beautiful film that promised a lot and didn't quite deliver. Not bad, and not one that made me fume, but they cheated way more than they should be allowed to.

B000H305U0|4.0|It's always good to see people recover from their mistakes. The tracks are very different from each other, and both the producing and vocal ends come together to make some really gripping music.  However, the one area where Justin does fall short, though, is in the songwriting.  While he sometimes comes up with innovative lyrics, he occasionally gets lazy and starts using the cliche R&B words and phrases.  Simplicity is fine, but not when your subject matter is pretty much the same!  He should sit down and listen to The Miseducation of Lauryn Hill the next time he's thinking of writing a song.  A little vocabulary lesson can go a long way. <br /> <br />My only other gripe is that I wasvery excited to see that I was getting the Best Buy Exclusive bonus track \\"Pose\\" (featuring Snoop Dogg) when I bought my CD.  Sadly, I was disappointed by it and wish it never would have been put on.  To me, it sounds like Jay-Z's \\"Change Clothes\\" would sound if the lyrics were severely dumbed down. <br /> <br />To me, the stand-out track on the album is \\"What Goes Around Comes Around\\".  It sounds like it's pretty obviously a powerful diss to Britney Spears, following up on his \\"Cry Me A River\\" single.  Similarly, the melodies and harmonies are just as powerful as the venom-laced lyrics--the main difference in this song being that Justin seems to be implying that he has found all the closure he needs by seeing her personal life and career begin to nosedive.  Brilliant move, Justin.  You (and America) are better off without her!

B00005NKKY|5.0|\\"Bookends\\" shows a leap in creativity for Simon & Garfunkel, having been allowed more studio time by their record company, Columbia to really harness their craft and the end result is truly a work of art.  Their first album, \\"Wednesday Morning 3AM\\" showed Paul and Art in a purely 1960's folk music light, while their next two albums, \\"Sounds of Silence\\" and \\"Parsley, Sage, Rosemary and Thyme\\" saw the duo enhance a \\"folk rock\\" style with some wonderful, sometimes whimsical melodies and beautifully poetic lyrics. Here on \\"Bookends\\" though, it feels as though Simon & Garfunkel have grown up. There's a more mature approach to the songwriting, the performances and to the production. They sound like young men with old heads on their shoulders, which could be seen as ironic as this album's theme (or at least side one of it) is one of aging. Paul and Art chose to start the album somewhat up tempo, moving to songs of reflection and ending with something slower and simpler, all in all to reflect the growing up and growing old in life while bookending the songs with a \\"Bookends\\" theme.<br /><br />Following the short \\"Bookends\\" theme intro, the album bursts open with the vibrant \\"Save The Life Of My Child\\" before settling down with \\"America\\". The imagery created by the lyrics in this song is made all the more vivid by the soft tones Paul Simon sings it in before Simon & Garfunkel's unfailing harmonies crescendo to lead the song into an instrumental fade. The song is such a wonderful tale of a young, innocent, naive couple, clearly in love and looking for adventure with no real direction, while at the same time looking for themselves. You can really imagine the sense of fun and excitement the couple are having on the Greyhound bus they boarded in Pittsburgh when Paul sings, \\"Laughing on the bus playing games with the faces. She said the man in the gabardine suit was a spy. I said be careful his bowtie is really a camera\\". Towards the end of the song it feels as though the fun has subsided as something unpretentious makes Paul sing, \\"Cathy I'm lost I said though I knew she was sleeping. I'm empty and aching and I don't know why\\". Cathy was the name of Paul Simon's girlfriend at the time, so the song at that point really seems \\"first person\\" in narrative, perhaps based on a real life experience. It's a fascinating song whatever. \\"Overs\\" is a very simplistic song of dilemma. Simon feels his relationship with his girlfriend/wife has run its course after a long period of time (\\"We're just a habit, like saccharin\\", he sings), but each time he feels he has gained enough courage to break off the relationship he stops and reconsiders. Why he reconsiders is not clear. Perhaps after being in the relationship so long he's actually more afraid of being alone. The album's theme of growing older is addressed here with Art Garfunkel's beautiful bridge where he sings, \\"Time is tapping on my forehead, Hanging from my mirror, Rattling the teacups.\\" \\"Voices Of Old People\\" is literally just that, with some quite strange comments made by the elderly voices recorded. This leads into \\"Old Friends\\" which is a perfect musical metaphor for slowing down, reflecting on life and now finding it \\"terribly strange to be 70\\". We all hope to reach 70 some day, but at the same time we can't really imagine ourselves being that age.<br /><br />With the album's linking theme completed on Side One, Side Two continues with a very similar style in songwriting and sound. \\"Fakin' It\\" tells of Paul Simon's distrust of the 1960's \\"flower power\\" movement with the line, \\"And a walk in the garden wears me down\\". It has an infectious drum track at the end and features an interesting break in the song where, from out of nowhere, a girl with a Lancashire accent (from northwest England) is heard supposedly entering a shop and says, \\"Good Morning, Mr. Leech. Have you had a busy day?\\". \\"Punky's Dilemma\\" is a fun song and unavoidably comes across as such with lyrics like, \\"Wish I was an Englishmuffin, 'Bout to make the most out of a toaster. I'd ease myself down, Comin' up brown\\". The album concludes with three very recognizable songs from the Simon & Garfunkel songbook - one of their biggest hits, \\"Mrs. Robinson\\" from the soundtrack to the hit movie, \\"The Graduate\\", along with \\"A Hazy Shade Of Winter\\" and \\"At The Zoo.\\"<br /><br />\\"Bookends\\" tends to get overshadowed by its follow-up, \\"Bridge Over Troubled Water\\" which went on to become one of the most successful and biggest-selling albums of all time and the winner of five Grammy awards. Whilst it deserved every bit of success and acclaim, the only minor criticism Paul Simon later leant to the \\"Troubled Water\\" album was that it might have been slightly overproduced. Compared to \\"Bookends\\" this does ring true and as a consequence it feels a little more \\"serious\\" in its approach. \\"Bookends\\" at least adopts more of an air of looseness and fun, despite not sounding as instantly commercial as the \\"Troubled Water\\" album. For me, \\"Bookends\\" is the quintessential Simon & Garfunkel album with the duo on peak form before their personal and professional differences interfered with their relationship. In 1968 they were riding the wave of their success through a collection of classic songs that perfectly reflect the time in which they were composed and recorded.ish muffin, 'Bout to make the most out of a toaster. I'd ease myself down, Comin' up brown\\". The album concludes with three very recognizable songs from the Simon & Garfunkel songbook - one of their biggest hits, \\"Mrs. Robinson\\" from the soundtrack to the hit movie, \\"The Graduate\\", along with \\"A Hazy Shade Of Winter\\" and \\"At The Zoo.\\" <br /> <br />\\"Bookends\\" tends to get overshadowed by its follow-up, \\"Bridge Over Troubled Water\\" which went on to become one of the most successful and biggest-selling albums of all time and the winner of five Grammy awards. Whilst it deserved every bit of success and acclaim, the only minor criticism Paul Simon later leant to the \\"Troubled Water\\" album was that it might have been slightly overproduced. Compared to \\"Bookends\\" this does ring true and as a consequence it feels a little more \\"serious\\" in its approach. \\"Bookends\\" at least adopts more of an air of looseness and fun, despite not sounding as instantly commercial as the \\"Troubled Water\\" album. For me, \\"Bookends\\" is the quintessential Simon & Garfunkel album with the duo on peak form before their personal and professional differences interfered with their relationship. In 1968 they were riding the wave of their success through a collection of classic songs that perfectly reflect the time in which they were composed and recorded. <br />

The Nazis did not need religion or faith to begin their reign of terror; you knew when the SS had been through a town because they would burn churches and break the legs of crucifixes (you can read interviews with German soldiers detailing these eyewitness accounts and testifying that the SS took blood oaths to destroy Christ, but I digress). Yes, the Nazis at first made deals with the Catholic Church, hiding their sins and portraying themselves as Christian, but we now know the truth. B00004VXF2|5.0|This album without doubt represents the zenith of Lou Reed's output, although admittedly it's not everyone's cup of tea.  I once heard a theory that it is an aural portrayal of the four seasons of the year, and it may just have something going for it, if you have another, closer listen, preferably with headphones.  MMM Part One develops a number of bright, fresh spring-like themes that repeated listening make more apparent.  These develop through MMM Part Two into warmer deeper tones, bringing forth images of summer, with some starkly conflicting themes towards the end, which presage MMM Part 3, which is strongly marked by a number of desperate aural clashes as each channel fights for supremacy.  But all too soon it's winter, indicated by MMM Part 4's more sombre, rueful tones, the repetitive rhythmic theme which this music ends with symbolising the cyclical nature of time.  Highlights must be the whole of MMM Part 3 (except for an annoying 30 seconds or so around 9:10) and the last six minutes of MMM Part 1, until just before it segues into MMM Part 2.  I've read that Hal Leonard Music are still working on the guitar tabs, one can only hope they get them out there soon.  A couple of demos or studio outtakes would have earned this CD six stars.

Unfortunately, the recording is a sludgy, mangled, over-gained mess.  Instruments and vocals get lost in the mix and the drums regularly peak out. His drumming on this album is nowhere near the tightness of Maiden's \\"golden\\" period.  The up-tempo parts feel heavy, like the band is dragging extra weight around.  And don't even get me started on the sloppy, abrupt, mid-song tempo changes!  I've seen Maiden live a number of times and Nicko is usually spot-on, so it's possible that to a certain extent the poor production detracts from his performance on the record.  But now we're splitting hairs. <br /> <br />To sum it up, BRAVE NEW WORLD was a decent effort but the two albums since then have been disappointments.  Regrettably, I don't think the band will ever be able to recapture the spark of their glory days, but I'm glad their still around.  They are the godfathers.
6302902010|5.0|Several other users have said everything I'm going to, but their opinions may get lost amongst the overwhelming majority of comments lamenting the unavailability of the 1959 film version of \\"Porgy & Bess\\".  Let's just get some of the basic facts straight again.<br /><br />The \\"original\\" production of \\"Porgy & Bess\\" as an opera took place in 1935 on stage.  Even this premiere presentation was abridged, both to conform to the conventions of Broadway (where it was originally presented), and to spare the voices of the leads, particularly Porgy (which is why the \\"Buzzard Song\\" was cut from the first production).<br /><br />In a sense, the first time the opera was presented as Gershwin truly envisioned it was by the Houston Grand Opera in 1976, with the full score restored, as well as the recitative passages which were frequently changed to spoken dialogue in earlier productions.<br /><br />The film version was an aberration-- I've never seen it, but have read quite a bit about it, and it seems clear that this version was intended as more of a musical than an opera.  Also, most of the parts were dubbed by other singers, so those who complain about about this issue on the current DVD release of the Glyndebourne production should bear that in mind.<br /><br />The Gershwin estate *is* responsible for squashing any trace of the PReminger film, which I think is a shame if only for reasons of artistic free speech, but the censorship becomes more understandable when you see how many Amazon.com users have posted comments that demonstrate the 1959 film is, to a large degree, what the public sees as the true \\"Porgy & Bess\\".  And this is after almost 50 years of supressing the film from public view!<br /><br />OK, so all the above said, what about the Glyndebourne DVD?  I think it's exceptionally well done, but share some of the reservations noted by others:  the lip synching is distractingly off at points (particularly if you're watching on a large screen TV); I find the sound mixing occassionally off, sometimes drowning out the vocal lines.<br /><br />But these are minor quibbles.  I can't imagine a true operatic trreatment as a film.  I can't even think of a precedent.  It's taken for granted that cinematic presentations of Shakespeare will be abridged, rearrange, and reinterpreted, and the same holds true for film treatments of opera.  The forms just don't naturally jell.<br /><br />Television can present opera as opera, with just enough opening up of the action to prevent the story from feeling static or stagebound.  And I think Trevor Nunn has done just this, with some creative and original interpretations of his own.  Whether you like the change he's made to the ending or not, I think you have to admire the creativity behind it.  It's certainly not exploitative.  At worst, it's a bit sentimental.  I find it inspiring, in a metaphorical way.  I don't think the miracle is meant to be taken quite literally.<br /><br />The performances are uniformally excellent, powerful and dignified.  I was personally most impressed by Cynthia Haymon as Bess, who is really the only character to undergo a major transformation through the course of the story.  She is believable, earthily beatiful, and the sympathy you feel for her intensifies the heartbreaking tragedy of her fate.<br /><br />Those who have complained about the acting performances simply don't understand that opera acting is generally stylized, similarly to silent film acting.  There's also an unfortunate history of only semi-competent acting in the opera world, but I can't point to a single weak link in the cast of this DVD production.<br /><br />This is a creative, faithful adaptation for television of the opera as it was intended to be seen by Gershwin himself.  The 1959 film should be available for contemporary evaluation, but it's simply unfair to knock this wonderful 1993 prodcution on the basis of dimly nostalgic memories of the lost Preminger film.  I do wish the sound were a bit better, and that the lip synching was better matched to the dubbed vocals, but these are intellectual, trivial criticisms of what I find to be a musically and emotionally powerful presentation of Gershwin's masterpiece.sh the sound were a bit better, and that the lip synching was better matched to the dubbed vocals, but these are intellectual, trivial criticisms of what I find to be a musically and emotionally powerful presentation of Gershwin's masterpiece.
